$('.article-top-widget').on('click', '.ati-toggle-trigger', function () {\r\n            $(this).find('.icon-general-add, .icon-minus').toggleClass('icon-minus icon-general-add');\r\n            $(this).siblings('.ati-toggle-content').toggleClass('hide');\r\n        });\r\n\r\n        // In Chrome, an anchor tag with target=\"_blank\" and a \"mailto:\" href opens a new tab/window as well as the email client\r\n        // I suspect this behavior will be corrected in the future\r\n        // Remove the target=\"_blank\"\r\n        $('ul.wi-affiliationList').find('a[href^=\"mailto:\"]').each(function () {\r\n            $(this).removeAttr('target');\r\n        });\r\n    });\r\n</script>\r\n\r\n \n    </div>\n    <div class=\"toolbar-item\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ToolboxGetCitation widget-instance-OUP_Get_Citation\">\n        <a href=\"#\" class=\"js-cite-button\" data-reveal-id=\"getCitation\" data-reveal><i class=\"icon-read-more\"></i><span>Cite</span></a>\r\n\r\n<div id=\"getCitation\" class=\"reveal-modal\" data-reveal>\r\n    <h3 class=\"modal-title\">Cite</h3>\r\n        <div class=\"oxford-citation-text\">\r\n            <p>Anton T Jaelani, Anupreeta More, Masamune Oguri, Alessandro Sonnenfeld, Sherry H Suyu, Cristian E Rusu, Kenneth C Wong, James H H Chan, Issha Kayo, Chien-Hsiu Lee, Dani C-Y Chao, Jean Coupon, Kaiki T Inoue, Toshifumi Futamase,  Survey of Gravitationally lensed Objects in HSC Imaging (SuGOHI) \u2013 V. Group-to-cluster scale lens search from the HSC\u2013SSP Survey, <em>Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society</em>, Volume 495, Issue 1, June 2020, Pages 1291\u20131310, <a href=\"https://doi.org/10.1093/mnras/staa1062\">https://doi.org/10.1093/mnras/staa1062</a></p>\r\n        </div>\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"citation-download-wrap\">\r\n        <form action=\"/Citation/Download\" method=\"get\" id=\"citationModal\">\r\n            <input type=\"hidden\" name=\"resourceId\" value=\"5823146\" />\r\n            <input type=\"hidden\" </div>\n\r\n                        </li>\r\n                        <li class=\"toolbar-item item-tools\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ToolboxPermissions widget-instance-OUP_Get_Permissions\">\n            <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n        <a href=\"https://s100.copyright.com/AppDispatchServlet?publisherName=OUP&amp;publication=1365-2966&amp;title=Survey%20of%20Gravitationally%20lensed%20Objects%20in%20HSC%20Imaging%20(SuGOHI)%20%E2%80%93%20V.%20Group-to-cluster%20scale%20lens%20search%20from%20the%20HSC%E2%80%93SSP%20Survey&amp;publicationDate=2020-04-21&amp;volumeNum=495&amp;issueNum=1&amp;author=Jaelani%2C%20Anton%20T%3B%20More%2C%20Anupreeta&amp;startPage=1291&amp;endPage=1310&amp;contentId=10.1093%2Fmnras%2Fstaa1062&amp;oa=&amp;copyright=Oxford%20University%20Press&amp;orderBeanReset=True\"              <i class=\"icon-general-arrow-filled-down arrow-icon\"></i>\r\n                                </div>\r\n                            </a>\r\n                            <ul id=\"ShareDrop\" class=\"addthis_toolbox addthis_default_style addthis_20x20_style f-dropdown\" data-dropdown-content aria-label=\"submenu\">\r\n                                <div class=\"nav-link mobile-account-signin dummy-link js-header-account-info-user-fullname\" id=\"header-account-info-user-fullname-mobile\">\r\n                    \r\nSign In                    <i class=\"dropdown-signin-form\">\r\n                        <div class=\"spinner\"></div>\r\n                    </li>\r\n                </ul>\r\n            </li>\r\n                <li class=\"site-menu-item site-menu-lvl-0\">\r\n                        <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"nav-link mobile-account-institution dummy-link\">\r\n                            Eccles Health Sci                         <li class=\"dropdown-institution-item\">\r\n\r\nEccles Health Sci Lib-Serials\r\n                            </li>\r\n\r\n                        <li class=\"dropdown-institution-signout\">\r\n                        </li>\r\n                    </ul>\r\n                </li>\r\n                            <li class=\"site-menu-item\">\r\n                    <a href=\"/my-account/register?siteId=5326&amp;returnUrl=%2fmnras%2farticle%2f495%2f1%2f1291%2f5823146\" class=\"register nav-link\">Register</a>\r\n                </li>\r\n       <nav class=\"navbar-menu\">\r\n\r\n        </nav>\r\n            <div class=\"navbar-search-container js-navbar-search-container\">\r\n                <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"navbar-search-close js_close-navsearch\">Close</a>\r\n                    <div class=\"navbar-search\">\r\n                        <div id=\"MicrositeSearch\" class=\"microsite-search\">\r\n                            <label for=\"navbar-search-filter\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search filter</label>\r\n                            <select class=\"navbar-search-filter\" id=\"navbar-search-filter\">\r\n                                                                    <optgroup label=\"Search within this journal\">\r\n label=\"Search beyond this journal\">\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"Parent\" >All  RAS Journals</option>\r\n       </select>\r\n\r\n                            <label for=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search input</label>\r\n                            <input class=\"navbar-search-input microsite-search-term\" type=\"text\" maxlength=\"255\" id=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" title=\"search input\">\r\n\r\n                            <a href=\"javascript:;\" id=\"MicrositeSearchIcon\"     <div class=\"navbar-search-advanced\"><a href=\"/mnras/advanced-search\" class=\"advanced-search js-advanced-search\">Advanced Search</a></div>\r\n            </div>            <div class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \n    </div>\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=204072599 id=\"204072599\" class=\"abstract-title\" >ABSTRACT</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">We report the largest sample of candidate strong gravitational lenses belonging to the Survey of Gravitationally lensed Objects in HSC Imaging for group-to-cluster scale (SuGOHI-c) systems. These candidates are compiled from the S18A data release of the Hyper Suprime-Cam Subaru Strategic Program (HSC\u2013SSP) Survey. We visually inspect \u223c39\u2009500 galaxy clusters, selected from several catalogues, overlapping with the Wide, Deep, and UltraDeep fields, spanning the cluster redshift range of 0.05\u00a0&lt; <em>z</em><sub>cl</sub>\u00a0&lt; 1.38. We discover 641 candidate lens systems, of which 536 are new. From the full sample, 47 are almost certainly bona fide lenses, 181 of them are highly probable lenses, and 413 are possible lens systems. Additionally, we present 131 lens candidates at galaxy scale serendipitously discovered during the inspection. We obtained spectroscopic follow-up of 10 candidates using the X-shooter. With this follow-up, we confirm eight systems as strong gravitational lenses. Of the remaining two, one of the sources is too faint to detect any emission, and the other has a tentative redshift close to the lens redshift, but additional arcs in this system are yet to be observed spectroscopically. Since the HSC\u2013SSP is an ongoing survey, we expect to find \u223c600 definite or probable lenses using this procedure and even more if combined with other lens finding methods.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;methods: observational&quot;\">methods: observational</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"surveys\">surveys</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: clusters: general&quot;\">galaxies: clusters: general</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=204072601 id=\"204072601\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The standard model of cosmology suggests that the Universe is dominated by dark matter and dark energy. Strong gravitational lensing is a phenomenon where multiple-lensed images of distant sources can be seen due to deflection by the gravity of intervening massive objects such as galaxies and galaxy clusters. Gravitational lensing has been shown to be a promising technique to probe these dark components. Lensing has been used to study distant galaxies with extreme magnification (e.g. Swinbank et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib83\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib83\" data-open=\"bib83\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Zitrin\u00a0&amp; Broadhurst <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib97\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib97\" data-open=\"bib97\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Richard et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>), infer substructure in the lensing haloes (e.g. More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Vegetti, Czoske\u00a0&amp; Koopmans <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib89\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib89\" data-open=\"bib89\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010a</a>; Vegetti et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib90\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib90\" data-open=\"bib90\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010b</a>; Hezaveh et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), constrain the Hubble constant (e.g. Suyu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib82\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib82\" data-open=\"bib82\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Bonvin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Wong et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib95\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib95\" data-open=\"bib95\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>), and place constraints on the slope of the inner density profile of the lensing haloes (e.g. Koopmans\u00a0&amp; Treu <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>; Koopmans et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Barnab\u00e8 et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Koopmans et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This has motivated dedicated efforts to search for gravitational lenses in large astronomical surveys e.g. the Hyper Suprime-Cam Subaru Strategic Program (HSC\u2013SSP) Survey (Aihara et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>), DESI Legacy Imaging Surveys (Dey et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>), Kilo Degree Survey (KiDS, de Jong et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), and Dark Energy Survey (DES, Dark Energy Survey Collaboration <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). Specifically, large imaging and spectroscopic surveys have allowed inferences of statistical properties of lenses such as constraints on the stellar initial mass function (e.g. Ferreras et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Treu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib86\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib86\" data-open=\"bib86\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Sonnenfeld et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib80\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib80\" data-open=\"bib80\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>), estimation of the fraction of dark matter in galaxy-scale haloes (e.g. Gavazzi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Grillo <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Faure et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Ruff et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>), and even constraints on cosmology (e.g. Gladders et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>; Oguri et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib69\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib69\" data-open=\"bib69\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">As mentioned above, most of the surveys have primarily focused on studying galaxy-scale or cluster-scale structures. As a result, the matter distribution in galaxies and galaxy clusters is relatively well studied via both strong and weak lensing. A further improvement in our understanding has come from the use of complementary methods to lensing such as stellar kinematics, satellite kinematics, and X-ray scaling relations. In contrast, there has not been much progress (in the last decade) on mass distributions of galaxy groups in the mass range of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$10^{12}\\!\\!-\\!\\!10^{14} {\\, \\mathrm{M}_{\\odot }}$|\u2060</span>, intermediate to galaxies and galaxy clusters. Using X-ray samples to study the intra-group medium at low redshifts (Helsdon\u00a0&amp; Ponman <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>), mass-to-light ratios of groups from the Canadian Network for Observational Cosmology 2 (CNOC 2) sample (e.g. Parker et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>), the faint end of the luminosity function of nearby compact groups (e.g. Krusch et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>), the concentration\u2013mass (<em>c</em> \u2212 <em>M</em>) relation of groups (e.g. Mandelbaum, Seljak\u00a0&amp; Hirata <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Newman, Ellis\u00a0&amp; Treu <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), colours and star formation of galaxy groups (e.g. Balogh et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>), scaling relations of X-ray selected groups (Rines\u00a0&amp; Diaferio <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib74\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib74\" data-open=\"bib74\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), and baryon fractions from the Two Micron All Sky Survey (2MASS) (Dai et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) are some examples of investigations of galaxy groups.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We still do not have a detailed understanding of the matter distribution, formation, and evolution of galaxy groups. Being one of the important components in the hierarchical assembly of structures in the Universe, galaxy groups are much more massive than galaxy-scale haloes and are concentrated enough to act as lenses. Furthermore, since galaxy groups are quite abundant compared to massive structures like galaxy clusters, the probability of finding group-scale lenses is also large. Hence, strong lensing can be successfully used to study group-scale haloes (Limousin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Fo\u00ebx et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Verdugo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib91\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib91\" data-open=\"bib91\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Newman et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In this work, we conduct a systematic search of group- and cluster-scale lenses as part of the Survey of Gravitationally lensed Objects in HSC Imaging (SuGOHI) and also present the results of spectroscopic follow-up of a sub-sample of these systems. The galaxy-scale lens sample (SuGOHI-g) is presented in Sonnenfeld et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib79\" data-open=\"bib79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), Sonnenfeld et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib80\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib80\" data-open=\"bib80\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>), and Wong et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib94\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib94\" data-open=\"bib94\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), and the results of a search for lensed quasars (SuGOHI-q) are reported in Chan et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>). This paper is organized as follows. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>, we describe the HSC\u2013SSP imaging data used in our search. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a>, we describe the procedure for finding new strong gravitational lens systems. We present our newly discovered lens candidates in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a>, we describe our spectroscopic follow-up observation. We present our summary and conclusion in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6\"></span><a href=\"#sec6\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">6</a>.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=204072607 id=\"204072607\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>2 THE DATA</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The Subaru Strategic Program (SSP) survey is carried out with the Hyper Suprime-Cam (HSC, Coupon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Furusawa et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Huang et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Kawanomoto et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Komiyama et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Miyazaki et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), a <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$1.7\\,\\deg ^2$|</span> field-of-view optical camera recently installed on the 8.2-m <em>Subaru telescope</em>. The HSC\u2013SSP Survey has three fields: the Wide field is expected to cover a 1400\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> area in five bands (<em>g, r, i, z</em>, and <em>y</em>) to an <em>i</em>-band depth of 26.2 by its completion, while the Deep+UltraDeep fields are expected to cover smaller areas of about 27\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> and 3.5\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup>, respectively [see Aihara et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>) for more details about the survey]. We use the photometric data from the S18A data release, which covers 1114\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> (out of which 305\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> is full depth) in Wide and 31\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> in Deep+UltraDeep, at least in one filter and one exposure (Aihara et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). The data are processed with the reduction pipeline <span class=\"small-caps\">hscpipe v6.7</span> (Bosch et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), a version of the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope stack (Axelrod et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Juri\u0107 et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Ivezi\u0107 et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). The median seeing of S18A data is 0.61\u00a0arcsec in the <em>i</em>band, 0.85\u00a0arcsec in the <em>g</em> band, and the pixel scale of HSC is 0.168\u00a0arcsec.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The redshifts used in this work are obtained from the photometric redshift catalogue of the HSC\u2013SSP Survey, determined using the Direct Empirical Photometric code (<span class=\"monospace\">DEmP</span>, Hsieh\u00a0&amp; Yee <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). The HSC\u2013SSP photometric redshifts are most accurate at 0.2 \u2272 <em>z</em><sub>phot</sub> \u2272 1.5. The point estimates of the photometric redshift are accurate to better than 1\u00a0per\u2009cent in terms of \u3008\u0394<em>z</em>/(1 + <em>z</em>)\u3009 with a scatter of \u22480.04 and an outlier rate of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\approx 8{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|</span> for galaxies with <em>i</em>\u00a0&lt; 24\u00a0mag. A more detailed description of <span class=\"monospace\">DEmP</span>\u2019s application to the HSC\u2013SSP data is presented in Tanaka et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib85\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib85\" data-open=\"bib85\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Since the HSC\u2013SSP Survey footprint has some overlap with that of the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS), we also extracted spectroscopic redshifts, whenever available, from the SDSS Data Release 15 (Aguado et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) catalogues.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=204072610 id=\"204072610\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>3 LENS CANDIDATE SELECTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this section, we describe how the cluster catalogues are selected for visual inspection and our criteria to grade the lens candidates. Visual inspection of cluster catalogues is still a practically useful method for lens finding at group/cluster scales because it allows for selection of candidates with rich diversity and complexity while maintaining high purity. We used the <span class=\"small-caps\">hscmap (sky explorer)</span>,<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">1</a></sup> an online tool, to visually inspect colour images of the clusters (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.1</a>). The lens search relied on morphology and colour information to visually analyse properties of the lensed images and the galaxies in the cluster to assess the plausibility of lensing. Inspectors could control the spatial scales, contrast, and brightness, and could choose different combinations of the HSC filters.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=204072612 id=\"204072612\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1>3.1 Parent catalogues</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We used galaxy cluster catalogues within the footprint covering the HSC\u2013SSP S18A imaging. The on-sky distribution of these clusters, along with survey footprints, is shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. We also give the number of clusters detected from each of the four catalogues in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"204072614\" scrollto-destination=\"204072614\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/495/1/10.1093_mnras_staa1062/1/m_staa1062fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611448910&amp;Signature=w8MkyY2lkAXsQ7kT~e5Kcssabu9elaZg8qH8nWIDCQKQ2EKpwexzn0FRR7hIdEyZ6PsSUllRE3WjHukM6yReeds~HRaOGS3I9S75p4OH4zcLt-BphGQy0I6rve64KGdTIQoSOC60EayIzEgtvAmACGlrWfgm0CfzLxaNmhZ3evbKd8XoXIleAwRqiAEtARCIILYZnu-lgTJVxCc88g-y7KBWoNtH9I4wnaSEOdvKcMaOZuIJ0rItAjxz-7h~u8KeGhr7SlkFlON7aAWNdEkjomUMHQkHoy1cW2w62bJx6WiZYKsajdJeGyHE71ZC9LvaqqS1tPVr7oxY0iVuPHcHQw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The Hyper Suprime-Cam Subaru Strategic Program (HSC\u2013SSP) observational footprint shown in equatorial coordinates. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib77\" data-open=\"bib77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>)\u00a0</td><td>R\u00a0</td><td>2968\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Wen, Han\u00a0&amp; Liu (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib93\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib93\" data-open=\"bib93\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>)\u00a0</td><td>W\u00a0</td><td>12\u2009000\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/204072615\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Clusters found in the HSC\u2013SSP S18A footprint from different algorithms, some of which are external to the HSC Survey collaboration.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Catalogue<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Catalogue label<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Number of clusters<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><span class=\"small-caps\">camira</span>\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"small-caps\">Cam</span>\u00a0</td><td>14\u2009992\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Ford et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>)\u00a0</td><td>F\u00a0</td><td>9475\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Rykoff et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib77\" data-open=\"bib77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>)\u00a0</td><td>R\u00a0</td><td>2968\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Wen, Han\u00a0&amp; Liu (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib93\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib93\" data-open=\"bib93\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>)\u00a0</td><td>W\u00a0</td><td>12\u2009000\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Catalogue<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Catalogue label<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Number of clusters<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><span class=\"small-caps\">camira</span>\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"small-caps\">Cam</span>\u00a0</td><td>14\u2009992\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Ford et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>)\u00a0</td><td>F\u00a0</td><td>9475\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Rykoff et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib77\" data-open=\"bib77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>)\u00a0</td><td>R\u00a0</td><td>2968\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Wen, Han\u00a0&amp; Liu (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib93\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib93\" data-open=\"bib93\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>)\u00a0</td><td>W\u00a0</td><td>12\u2009000\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/204072615\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=204072616 id=\"204072616\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1-1>3.1.1 Clusters from the HSC\u2013SSP Survey</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Our primary cluster catalogue is called <span class=\"small-caps\">camira</span>, which is produced by running the cluster-finding algorithm (Oguri <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) on the internal HSC\u2013SSP data release S18A<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn2\" data-open=\"fn2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">2</a></sup> (Aihara et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>), covering roughly 465\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> and 28\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup>, in all five filters, for Wide and Deep+UltraDeep fields, respectively. The <span class=\"small-caps\">camira</span> is validated through comparisons with existing spectroscopic and X-ray data as well as mock galaxy catalogues.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We obtain 14\u2009992 clusters, comprising of 14\u2009350 clusters from the Wide fields and 642 clusters from the Deep fields, with the richness limit <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$N_{\\rm ric,{\\small CAMIRA}}\\gt 10$|</span> spanning a redshift range of 0.1\u00a0&lt; <em>z</em><sub>cl</sub>\u00a0&lt; 1.38. Richness in <span class=\"small-caps\">camira</span> is defined to be the number of red member galaxies with stellar mass <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{\\rm star}\\ge 10^{10.2}{\\, \\mathrm{M}_{\\odot }}$|</span> lying within a physical radius of \u22481.4 Mpc. The richness limit <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$N_{\\rm ric,{\\small CAMIRA}}= 10$|</span> corresponds to <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{200}\\approx 7\\times 10^{13} {\\, \\mathrm{M}_{\\odot }}$|\u2060</span>, where <em>M</em><sub>200</sub> is the cluster mass within <em>r</em><sub>200</sub>, by extrapolating the richness-mass relation of <span class=\"small-caps\">camira</span> from Murata et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). <em>r</em><sub>200</sub> is the radius within which the mean density of a cluster is 200\u00a0times the critical density of the Universe. The cluster sample is shown by green points in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. The <span class=\"small-caps\">camira</span> cluster catalogue is still being constructed from the HSC\u2013SSP Survey data, since the HSC survey is an ongoing and several patches are likely to have incomplete imaging data, e.g. has \u22644 filters. As a result, we decided to make use of other public catalogues constructed from previous surveys that have overlapped with the HSC\u2013SSP Survey footprint, e.g. the SDSS (York et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib96\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib96\" data-open=\"bib96\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>) and the Canada-France Hawaii Telescope Lensing Survey (CFHTLenS, Heymans et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). Also, including more cluster catalogues maximizes the chance of finding more group-to-cluster scale lenses.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=204072619 id=\"204072619\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1-2>3.1.2 Clusters from data release 8 of SDSS-III data</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The HSC\u2013SSP Survey footprint has almost complete overlap with SDSS footprint. We thus have two extensive cluster catalogues, Wen et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib93\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib93\" data-open=\"bib93\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) and Rykoff et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib77\" data-open=\"bib77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), that can be used. Both catalogues are derived from the galaxy data of 14\u2009000\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> of SDSS-III (Eisenstein et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). Wen et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib93\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib93\" data-open=\"bib93\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) identified 132\u2009684 clusters (12\u2009000 of them overlap with the HSC\u2013SSP S18A footprint, see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> and red points in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>) in the redshift range of 0.05\u00a0\u2264 <em>z</em><sub>cl</sub>\u00a0&lt; 0.8. The clusters are selected if their richness <em>N</em><sub>ric, Wen</sub>\u00a0\u2265 12, which corresponds to <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{200}~\\approx ~0.6\\times 10^{14} {\\, \\mathrm{M}_{\\odot }}$|</span> and a number of member galaxies candidates <em>N</em><sub>200</sub>\u00a0\u2265 8 within <em>r</em><sub>200</sub>. We also used clusters from the red-sequence Matched-filter Probabilistic Percolation (<span class=\"small-caps\">redMaPPer</span>, for the details see Rykoff et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib76\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib76\" data-open=\"bib76\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) cluster finding algorithm (version 6.3). This catalogue has a total of 25\u2009236 clusters (2\u2009968 are overlapping with the HSC\u2013SSP S18A footprint, see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> and blue points in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>) in the redshift range of 0.08\u00a0\u2264 <em>z</em><sub>cl</sub>\u00a0&lt; 0.55 with <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$N_{\\rm ric,{{\\small RED}M{\\small A}PP{\\small ER}}}\\ge 20$|\u2060</span>, which corresponds to <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{200}\\gtrsim 10^{14} {\\, \\mathrm{M}_{\\odot }}$|\u2060</span>. For more detailed description of the catalogue, see Rykoff et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib77\" data-open=\"bib77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>).</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=204072621 id=\"204072621\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1-3>3.1.3 CFHTLenS data</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Ford et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) have a sample of 18\u2009056 clusters (9475 of them overlap with the HSC\u2013SSP S18A footprint, see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>) at redshifts 0.2\u00a0\u2264 <em>z</em><sub>cl</sub>\u00a0\u2264 0.9. The clusters have been detected using the 3D-Matched-Filter Galaxy Cluster Finder in the \u223c154\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> CFHTLenS survey (Milkeraitis et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Ford et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) with a significance \u22653.5 and richness <em>N</em><sub>ric, Ford</sub> &gt; 2, which corresponds to <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{200}~\\approx ~6 \\times 10^{12} {\\, \\mathrm{M}_{\\odot }}$|\u2060</span>. This field has a substantial overlap with the S18A data (see magenta points in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=204072623 id=\"204072623\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2>3.2 Ranking criteria</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We identified 39\u2009435 clusters, located in the HSC\u2013SSP S18A footprint, from the four catalogues combined. Inspectors use the online <span class=\"small-caps\">hscmap (sky explorer)</span><sup>1</sup> server to inspect colour images of the clusters (Aihara et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018b</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). In the first step, we divided the clusters into three redshift bins, which were inspected by three inspectors per redshift bin. After we compiled the 1160 candidates from all redshift bins combined, nine inspectors independently assigned a rank from 0 to 3, according to the following criteria:</p><ul class=\"list-simple\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">3: almost certainly a lens,</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">2: probably a lens,</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">1: possibly a lens, and</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">0: not a lens.</p></li></ul><p class=\"chapter-para\">We further refined the sample of candidates by applying the following scheme:</p><ul class=\"list-simple\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">A: <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm {\\langle Rank\\rangle }\\gt 2.5$|\u2060</span>,</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">B: <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$1.5\\lt \\rm {\\langle Rank\\rangle }\\le 2.5$|\u2060</span>,</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">C: <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$0.5\\lt \\rm {\\langle Rank\\rangle }\\le 1.5$|\u2060</span>, and</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Not a lens: <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm {\\langle Rank\\rangle }\\le 0.5$|</span></p></li></ul><p class=\"chapter-para\">where <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm {\\langle Rank\\rangle }$|</span> is the mean rank given by individual inspectors. The final sample, thus, consists of 772 candidates. Systems with highly discrepant ranks were discussed and regraded to mitigate such discrepancies.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=204072629 id=\"204072629\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>4 RESULTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The Einstein radius, \u03b8<sub>Eins</sub>, is the best parameter to represent mass of the lens, which can be approximated from the arc radius, <em>R</em><sub>arc</sub>\u00a0\u2248 2\u03b8<sub>Eins</sub> (More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). Typically, lensing haloes with \u03b8<sub>Eins</sub>\u00a0\u22652\u00a0arcsec are very massive lenses with significant contribution from the environment of the primary lensing galaxy (Oguri <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). Here, we calculated the arc radius by assuming a circle roughly covering the candidate arc centred on the brightest cluster galaxy (BCG).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Next, we separated the graded systems into two groups: SuGOHI-c and additional lenses at galaxy scale (SuGOHI-g, see Appendix\u00a0\u00a0<a class=\"js-jumplink\" href=\"#sec7\">A</a>), which are shown by Tables\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl6\" data-open=\"tbl6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A2</a>, respectively. The classification criteria for a candidate to be included in SuGOHI-c are the following:</p><ol class=\"number\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">If the lensing is due to the BCG (see the panel a in Fig.\u00a0 \u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>), and</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">either the angular separation of the arc from the lens centre, the arc radius, <em>R</em><sub>arc</sub>\u00a0\u2265 2\u00a0arcsec (e.g. HSC J1557+4206),</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">or if the lensing is caused by more than one galaxy enclosed by a ring through the arc or multiple images (e.g. HSC J2228+0022).</p></li></ol>                        <a id=\"204072633\" scrollto-destination=\"204072633\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/495/1/10.1093_mnras_staa1062/1/m_staa1062fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611448910&amp;Signature=MkRKJXWeHFMs0X0cDGQ2SUdPanxGm4K9s~9xgybJFdjZHKsSHWUqoJ9G2Wp73MDQK8vQlSqNhrgmgRM1ovftyergx9tCyiKfPAYk6SMchnYA33kOQI-UHohWQQPH1EDm7xEvsz~bBDKonCu4SR-7jXGDF7-2c3dd7QLwAptpwt5UAm-CD3SIVEkJ9YB9OrXqpcP1-nMtWaLZsNuIxrRlvfm8AK3UJDX1mIB5EV4SeKvCSViHHtKG1OIzbgkv0iFV9VT7HHdEXgdkV0rzfra8gTJ~Co1OgWGM2LVPIrdjKiHiLo55LZ~Nn686LuuLe4CyD7VUSfbSlmx8urT7MQpdqg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Types of lens candidates depending on their location with respect to galaxy clusters. Lens candidates where the BCG acts as a lens (panel a, e.g. HSC J1441\u20130053) or a member galaxy (see more description in Section\u00a04) acts as a lens (panel b, e.g. HSC J1234\u20130009) are classified as SuGOHI-g, otherwise as serendipitous discoveries (panels c and d, e.g. HSC J1414\u20130136 and HSC J0904+0102, for SuGOHI-c and -g, respectively). The cyan circles indicate member galaxies of a cluster and the brightest cluster galaxy (BCG) is indicated by a thicker circle. The white circle indicates the region that encloses member galaxies with the BCG at the centre. The richness Nric, cluster redshift zcl, and number of galaxy member Nmem are shown at the top left.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa1062fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/204072633/staa1062fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa1062fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"204072633\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/495/1/10.1093_mnras_staa1062/1/staa1062fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611448910&Signature=G6WEo6YGSeOqg-AirdKMU2CH89KrZrohD8j9xPpIhHFDGY8DEDUjCnzV5sImO~ktdqJHc5yCfd9g7cChs3bwmN6MvZqHilpQ6~6aqgFNS9EVSpYAN-MTNBcDFaChlL7SxTUMCvUL3dq6CuJSEZ7q~-kG6CAy8Nf1eSYe1-3hor6dLIrSq0xv0Bd20RukG9kGTMk-fHuCOLGOm-U~dAgHsMtBNRec7UeKozikpXgySIDTSyjUDhxr-OEmfqFM19wDZq8JwFdnbDEFtWAOxtYJfVxvZL3~baxEXisNAMhw-00KqVKpzPgLtPj5NoVfw2lZFpqNzdsms05qABjJ6xTrgQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=204072633&ar=5823146&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa1062fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Types of lens candidates depending on their location with respect to galaxy clusters. Lens candidates where the BCG acts as a lens (<strong>panel a</strong>, e.g. HSC J1441\u20130053) or a member galaxy (see more description in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>) acts as a lens (<strong>panel b</strong>, e.g. HSC J1234\u20130009) are classified as SuGOHI-g, otherwise as serendipitous discoveries (<strong>panels c and d</strong>, e.g. HSC J1414\u20130136 and HSC J0904+0102, for SuGOHI-c and -g, respectively). The cyan circles indicate member galaxies of a cluster and the brightest cluster galaxy (BCG) is indicated by a thicker circle. The white circle indicates the region that encloses member galaxies with the BCG at the centre. The richness <em>N</em><sub>ric</sub>, cluster redshift <em>z</em><sub>cl</sub>, and number of galaxy member <em>N</em><sub>mem</sub> are shown at the top left.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/495/1/10.1093_mnras_staa1062/1/m_staa1062fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611448910&amp;Signature=MkRKJXWeHFMs0X0cDGQ2SUdPanxGm4K9s~9xgybJFdjZHKsSHWUqoJ9G2Wp73MDQK8vQlSqNhrgmgRM1ovftyergx9tCyiKfPAYk6SMchnYA33kOQI-UHohWQQPH1EDm7xEvsz~bBDKonCu4SR-7jXGDF7-2c3dd7QLwAptpwt5UAm-CD3SIVEkJ9YB9OrXqpcP1-nMtWaLZsNuIxrRlvfm8AK3UJDX1mIB5EV4SeKvCSViHHtKG1OIzbgkv0iFV9VT7HHdEXgdkV0rzfra8gTJ~Co1OgWGM2LVPIrdjKiHiLo55LZ~Nn686LuuLe4CyD7VUSfbSlmx8urT7MQpdqg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Types of lens candidates depending on their location with respect to galaxy clusters. Lens candidates where the BCG acts as a lens (panel a, e.g. HSC J1441\u20130053) or a member galaxy (see more description in Section\u00a04) acts as a lens (panel b, e.g. HSC J1234\u20130009) are classified as SuGOHI-g, otherwise as serendipitous discoveries (panels c and d, e.g. HSC J1414\u20130136 and HSC J0904+0102, for SuGOHI-c and -g, respectively). The cyan circles indicate member galaxies of a cluster and the brightest cluster galaxy (BCG) is indicated by a thicker circle. The white circle indicates the region that encloses member galaxies with the BCG at the centre. The richness Nric, cluster redshift zcl, and number of galaxy member Nmem are shown at the top left.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa1062fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/204072633/staa1062fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa1062fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"204072633\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/495/1/10.1093_mnras_staa1062/1/staa1062fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611448910&Signature=G6WEo6YGSeOqg-AirdKMU2CH89KrZrohD8j9xPpIhHFDGY8DEDUjCnzV5sImO~ktdqJHc5yCfd9g7cChs3bwmN6MvZqHilpQ6~6aqgFNS9EVSpYAN-MTNBcDFaChlL7SxTUMCvUL3dq6CuJSEZ7q~-kG6CAy8Nf1eSYe1-3hor6dLIrSq0xv0Bd20RukG9kGTMk-fHuCOLGOm-U~dAgHsMtBNRec7UeKozikpXgySIDTSyjUDhxr-OEmfqFM19wDZq8JwFdnbDEFtWAOxtYJfVxvZL3~baxEXisNAMhw-00KqVKpzPgLtPj5NoVfw2lZFpqNzdsms05qABjJ6xTrgQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=204072633&ar=5823146&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa1062fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Types of lens candidates depending on their location with respect to galaxy clusters. Lens candidates where the BCG acts as a lens (<strong>panel a</strong>, e.g. HSC J1441\u20130053) or a member galaxy (see more description in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>) acts as a lens (<strong>panel b</strong>, e.g. HSC J1234\u20130009) are classified as SuGOHI-g, otherwise as serendipitous discoveries (<strong>panels c and d</strong>, e.g. HSC J1414\u20130136 and HSC J0904+0102, for SuGOHI-c and -g, respectively). The cyan circles indicate member galaxies of a cluster and the brightest cluster galaxy (BCG) is indicated by a thicker circle. The white circle indicates the region that encloses member galaxies with the BCG at the centre. The richness <em>N</em><sub>ric</sub>, cluster redshift <em>z</em><sub>cl</sub>, and number of galaxy member <em>N</em><sub>mem</sub> are shown at the top left.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">If none of the above are satisfied, candidates fall in the SuGOHI-g sample as being serendipitously discovered during the inspection [e.g. HSC J0904+0102 (Jaelani et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>), which is at a similar position to HSC J1414\u20130136 with respect to the cluster but has <em>R</em><sub>arc</sub>\u00a0&lt; 2\u00a0arcsec; see the panel c of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>] and are reported in the Appendix.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For the first classification criteria, if a BCG is misclassified<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn3\" data-open=\"fn3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">3</a></sup> as a member galaxy by the algorithm, only then do we accept it as a SuGOHI-c system. A member galaxy may be aided by the group potential, but then the arc separation also needs to be <em>R</em><sub>arc</sub>\u00a0\u2265 2\u00a0arcsec (see the middle panel in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>). Otherwise, this could still be a galaxy-scale lens. In some rare cases, an arc radius cannot be quantified because it is being deflected by multiple galaxies on either side (e.g. see HSC J0209\u20130448, grade C in the online material<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn4\" data-open=\"fn4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">4</a></sup>). These are also included as SuGOHI-c.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">A total of 641 systems (including 536 new lenses presented for the first time) are in the SuGOHI-c sample. These consist of 47 Grade A, 181 Grade B, and 413 Grade C systems, respectively. We found some candidate systems in more than one catalogue that are shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>. The <span class=\"small-caps\">camira</span> produces the largest number of candidate systems. We also found many candidates serendipitously that were missed by the parent cluster catalogues. Some of these lenses were also discovered independently by the citizen science project (<span class=\"small-caps\">space warps</span>, Marshall et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) from the HSC\u2013SSP Survey (see details in Sonnenfeld et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1_708_1588250588086\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1_708_1588250588086\" data-open=\"bib1_708_1588250588086\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>). We present the lens candidate statistics in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"204072637\" scrollto-destination=\"204072637\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/495/1/10.1093_mnras_staa1062/1/m_staa1062fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611448910&amp;Signature=37FuM3kUDgR3vIhcSDbm6Le5E2r-V-RvVwxBe55dHlrJsatmodgSrqQRNVNO541bliQmShQSYHh27D6LoW4TGS7MXsFZwzuzXQnP2klEMjwCsJR-CPTosee3rAl8RgAvZAGdQCZxoM99Kg51S20LTtMWHBjzEK1on32KpbMRVMjtsa1RiLqh~9WqT~KAEqlt0n2eCrafB6nkCtN3uPoLo1Mouz~-WYVYSqT5wXIfeyaIESEZ3BPcHnAbE4RFFteGGZqEt9H7D5LPoEWi8W4~NNSTrthz7Gy1qwAWKX8Zn428w8VpMC3Md3X1awBtupwO6zIDdIQ-xkm0kq380y0H7A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Distribution of lens candidates according to the parent cluster catalogues. The letters represent the parent cluster catalogues as presented in Table\u00a01. The Venn diagram is divided into two panels: 550 lens systems of SuGOHI-c correspond to the parent cluster (upper) and 91 lens systems that are serendipitously (bottom) discovered during the inspection and, thus, are not listed as BCGs of the clusters or members with Rarc\u00a0\u2265 2\u00a0arcsec.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa1062fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/204072637/staa1062fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa1062fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"204072637\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/495/1/10.1093_mnras_staa1062/1/staa1062fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611448910&Signature=KQChPzFUyiuKNWjNO~3u7j~ZotxSgRzCm-MGOyvZskodySbxG4ajqZ1lTx2d1bZeFHSOJq3nnmWvsRB6lqmIwVAdJuv9fo8Hz4rvKFDQdz~~CQPDMzYBNxXCwtRIVBbAj1pAb0t~GcDmaIq5PUG1tL~hLHJN5t0EkGfrTcfAdYMx04m8TwGO5dje~3hotI7OckBUKmjtc1-mYjsdoIWkkBac4wEYnWMMVx0Lz1zZNnUdTrTHQMjxu2GjyiehIpyljrgmP3gCHzNugbJhQcfALVtS9NfCT86e31iyx41GHGA7m-wp1qF1rmwNWCJHvFsBj2THQ1wrpNRaZicPgq6R7Q__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=204072637&ar=5823146&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa1062fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Distribution of lens candidates according to the parent cluster catalogues. The letters represent the parent cluster catalogues as presented in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. The Venn diagram is divided into two panels: 550 lens systems of SuGOHI-c correspond to the parent cluster (upper) and 91 lens systems that are serendipitously (bottom) discovered during the inspection and, thus, are not listed as BCGs of the clusters or members with <em>R</em><sub>arc</sub>\u00a0\u2265 2\u00a0arcsec.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/495/1/10.1093_mnras_staa1062/1/m_staa1062fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611448910&amp;Signature=37FuM3kUDgR3vIhcSDbm6Le5E2r-V-RvVwxBe55dHlrJsatmodgSrqQRNVNO541bliQmShQSYHh27D6LoW4TGS7MXsFZwzuzXQnP2klEMjwCsJR-CPTosee3rAl8RgAvZAGdQCZxoM99Kg51S20LTtMWHBjzEK1on32KpbMRVMjtsa1RiLqh~9WqT~KAEqlt0n2eCrafB6nkCtN3uPoLo1Mouz~-WYVYSqT5wXIfeyaIESEZ3BPcHnAbE4RFFteGGZqEt9H7D5LPoEWi8W4~NNSTrthz7Gy1qwAWKX8Zn428w8VpMC3Md3X1awBtupwO6zIDdIQ-xkm0kq380y0H7A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Distribution of lens candidates according to the parent cluster catalogues. .\u00a0</span></th><th>B<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>C<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>spectroscopically confirmed<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>SuGOHI-c\u00a0</td><td>47\u00a0</td><td>181\u00a0</td><td>413\u00a0</td><td>641\u00a0</td><td>105\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u2004<span class=\"small-caps\">Cam</span>\u00a0</td><td>21\u00a0</td><td>128\u00a0</td><td>202\u00a0</td><td>351\u00a0</td><td>68\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u2004F\u00a0</td><td>5\u00a0</td><td>15\u00a0</td><td>40\u00a0</td><td>60\u00a0</td><td>20\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u2004R\u00a0</td><td>20\u00a0</td><td>56\u00a0</td><td>136\u00a0</td><td>212\u00a0</td><td>40\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u2004W\u00a0</td><td>26\u00a0</td><td>79\u00a0</td><td>194\u00a0</td><td>299\u00a0</td><td>58\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u2004Serendipity\u00a0</td><td>6\u00a0</td><td>24\u00a0</td><td>61\u00a0</td><td>91\u00a0</td><td>12\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th colspan=\"3\">Grade<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Total<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Previously known /<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>A<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>B<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>C<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>spectroscopically confirmed<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>SuGOHI-c\u00a0</td><td>47\u00a0</td><td>181\u00a0</td><td>413\u00a0</td><td>641\u00a0</td><td>105\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u2004<span class=\"small-caps\">Cam</span>\u00a0</td><td>21\u00a0</td><td>128\u00a0</td><td>202\u00a0</td><td>351\u00a0</td><td>68\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u2004F\u00a0</td><td>5\u00a0</td><td>15\u00a0</td><td>40\u00a0</td><td>60\u00a0</td><td>20\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u2004R\u00a0</td><td>20\u00a0</td><td>56\u00a0</td><td>136\u00a0</td><td>212\u00a0</td><td>40\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u2004W\u00a0</td><td>26\u00a0</td><td>79\u00a0</td><td>194\u00a0</td><td>299\u00a0</td><td>58\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u2004Serendipity\u00a0</td><td>6\u00a0</td><td>24\u00a0</td><td>61\u00a0</td><td>91\u00a0</td><td>12\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/204072638\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We provide the full candidate systems of the SuGOHI-c in the online material<sup>3</sup>. The list of SuGOHI-c with grades A and B is presented in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>, which provides the system name, the equatorial coordinates, the lens and source redshift, the arc radius, the mean and the \u03c3 of the rank, a qualitative grade, the parent catalogue, and references from previous studies. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> show composite colour (<em>gri</em> or <em>riz</em>) cutouts of grades A and B for the SuGOHI-c sample. At the top of each cutout is the system name. At the bottom left is a grade (labelled 'A' or 'B'), as well as a label '<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathbb {C}$|</span>', '<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathbb {D}$|</span>', or '<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathbb {K}$|</span>' if the lens is spectroscopically confirmed, previously discovered, and well-known, respectively. The known candidates have been identified by cross-matching with the published systems in the literature, as reported in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"204072640\" scrollto-destination=\"204072640\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/495/1/10.1093_mnras_staa1062/1/m_staa1062fig4a.jpeg?Expires=1611448910&amp;Signature=Ap~fod1sloIvbN9gAz8NhLTOchvCk1Csq10wd0G-u3e1Z8UDWae-NoEItWYa~drIb1CnXqqxlKb3iSCP~KFVLxURp6JvOTbqyvOuQY1L6c3aztZ87IkiqBt1FINOc5zV8SMC8WWMBBVsCVPJr4CmrwC6RB6Rj5ceCVbpkJtM11mTuAMHM6Rt0951MzS0r-nFEbeRxQfbw1bJ2li8d43gkZNVj3wKzT0hdZOpBJXZsmaSkn4Ea3~s1WloqU5FpPjtb8obuZd3s-Y2Mbwms-lFoh53b9B1jwtqxVLB5UJaMYh5YUt5pCjdL~icD2BKCP-4DeSS4s17q9LP4qrLntya2Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"SuGOHI-c lens candidates with grades A and B (shown on the bottom left). Scale bars of 5\u00a0arcsec are displayed in the bottom right corner.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa1062fig4c.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/204072640/staa1062fig4c.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa1062fig4c.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"204072640\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/495/1/10.1093_mnras_staa1062/1/staa1062fig4c.jpeg?Expires=1611448910&amp;Signature=3JWxe-yt41DpanDmKeegOYOf32h9yhuTbNWOHfBUgVxwNzEthPknF7R11C2BQ4CM3l78yHVmHLgG3CmhkqVLjkDoH2ahYMsdBxqystAgN18rrDaNseO-c3RA92XdH2rVV4mWxLO01vmRLIIwRUiYf0NEH3oQqfoR4gg4tto~dc~KJPtE-20C-vJFgd1LgidZvqN6fTSdN6-U8RC7U0y0o4c5Q07363AJ0b6US72~14tEKQnwFZ-z0KJ59wllbq4U84iwnQJNtejAdAo~VKduaqDW~YAZpgx9cGaXdu6Zim7UQgWGlpbBhT~Io58JDJYQHfETIkzChRoNY4AE29aQ9A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&amp;sec=204072640&amp;ar=5823146&amp;xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&amp;imagename=&amp;siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa1062fig4c.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">SuGOHI-c lens candidates with grades A and B (shown on the bottom left). Spectroscopically confirmed, previously discovered, or known lenses are indicated by '<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathbb {C}$|</span>', '<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathbb {D}$|</span>', or '<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathbb {K}$|</span>', respectively. All images are oriented with North up and East left. Scale bars of 5\u00a0arcsec are displayed in the bottom right corner.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"204072641\" scrollto-destination=\"204072641\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl3\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl3\" data-id=\"tbl3\"><span class=\"label\">Table 3.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">SuGOHI-c candidates, with grades A and B, selected by visual inspection of galaxy cluster catalogues. Redshifts are <span class=\"monospace\">DEmP</span> photometric and SDSS DR15 spectroscopic redshifts. PC indicates the parent cluster catalogue through which a candidate was selected as in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. Systems with \u2020, <sup>X</sup>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$^{\\mathbb {C}}$|\u2060</span>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$^{\\mathbb {D}}$|\u2060</span>, and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$^{\\mathbb {K}}$|</span> are the lens candidates that have red-coloured sources, X-shooter follow-up, spectroscopically confirmed, previously discovered, and known, respectively. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>),<sup>17</sup>Tyson, Valdes\u00a0&amp; Wenk (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib87\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib87\" data-open=\"bib87\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1990</a>),<sup>18</sup>Limousin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>).</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/204072641\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl3\" data-id=\"tbl3\"><span class=\"label\">Table 3.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">SuGOHI-c candidates, with grades A and B, selected by visual inspection of galaxy cluster catalogues. Redshifts are <span class=\"monospace\">DEmP</span> photometric and SDSS DR15 spectroscopic redshifts. PC indicates the parent cluster catalogue through which a candidate was selected as in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. Systems with \u2020, <sup>X</sup>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$^{\\mathbb {C}}$|\u2060</span>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$^{\\mathbb {D}}$|\u2060</span>, and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$^{\\mathbb {K}}$|</span> are the lens candidates that have red-coloured sources, X-shooter follow-up, spectroscopically confirmed, previously discovered, and known, respectively.
