(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>),<sup>17</sup>Tyson, Valdes\u00a0&amp; Wenk (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib87\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib87\" data-open=\"bib87\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1990</a>),<sup>18</sup>Limousin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>), <sup>19</sup>Auger et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>).</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/204072641\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We show the photometric redshift distribution of lens galaxies and arc radii of the systems in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>, and for comparison, we also show 125 lens systems of the Strong Lensing Legacy Survey - ARCS (SARCS) sample distribution with <em>R</em><sub>arc</sub>\u00a0\u2265 2\u00a0arcsec from More et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). We find that the mean lens redshifts for the SuGOHI-c sample and SARCS sample are <em>z</em>\u00a0= 0.50\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.23 and <em>z</em>\u00a0= 0.58\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.22, respectively. We note that the mean redshifts of both samples have good agreement. We find that the peak of the SuGOHI-c lens sample, on the other hand, is at <em>z</em> \u223c 0.3\u20130.4, which is consistent with the peak expected from numerical simulation (Bartelmann et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"204072643\" scrollto-destination=\"204072643\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/495/1/10.1093_mnras_staa1062/1/m_staa1062fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611448910&amp;Signature=y~LTR~B8Dl~0nJhe2GE4msK3PSeuEx8DNrSCGhW3ccrXnsIQTzJuLh~Zo8dpbSEFgtMyzgIGjEBHOPBnj02Ml~iibRfCP-AdIjKJxeAX6n05zLpZkrnIEO~BI4NPnn5muIeWh8MknkjyitB5Q0vS2Do5QNi~m8~T5kZQgg2IUgJ7sfLlVKWiQW8fw1qMZMjrIjcOWEe5~Yg2r6CCy8qrxUBkdkQICQFCgfPqnp07MAsyLkxRWm-Vhcb2VnZu-JRFTib54dt0D7tUzHAtljWeHFoJNcl8n4QAsxD51cYbqIWuerWcx~kof3PDcWP-soQ0xq7bLaJI-7D8mnJ4Bjd-3Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Left: Photometric redshift distributions of group-to-cluster-scale lens candidates. The peak of the redshift distributions for both the SuGOHI-c sample (cyan) and the SARCS sample (magenta, More et\u00a0al. 2012) is around z \u223c 0.4. Right: The binned distribution of arc radii for Rarc\u00a0\u2265 2. The peak at around 3\u00a0arcsec attests to the fact that most of the candidates are, indeed, at group scales. As before, cyan and magenta show the SuGOHI-c and the SARCS samples, respectively.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa1062fig5.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/204072643/staa1062fig5.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa1062fig5.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"204072643\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/495/1/10.1093_mnras_staa1062/1/staa1062fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611448910&Signature=O29dAuRLZrg4uK3GizwZECsO~URKb7ed~SuxadPWm6U2784IhnPYJFpQPCnUKNu8Qc62S5EtQUS8vThgOT5lY0m50b7ocs4ADyCjCnt8sXoI20mcnBHRhRl7gS2nNHNHpGm-ExRyAMqvO4GTgqNK-V4b1ryUfeGWV2OXdWNL6dNyk5Jat5Ef9n2-HQkLbnJFT94kGKv7hs~Y~xKVPZsWoWUuIGwVFxZFOxWMv~EHYZ4NGUBPyQJma64K9PQYubdrXW~Z~oxvuAkiPhNefTykjLajWk1D9jTlo-61L5gvB7m1OJ0U~BV89mdp3lf7VDuOvnwAkuOX-RjDdGJ9Hb8dnQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=204072643&ar=5823146&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa1062fig5.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Left:</em> Photometric redshift distributions of group-to-cluster-scale lens candidates. The peak of the redshift distributions for both the SuGOHI-c sample (cyan) and the SARCS sample (magenta, More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) is around <em>z</em> \u223c 0.4. <em>Right:</em> The binned distribution of arc radii for <em>R</em><sub>arc</sub>\u00a0\u2265 2. The peak at around 3\u00a0arcsec attests to the fact that most of the candidates are, indeed, at group scales. As before, cyan and magenta show the SuGOHI-c and the SARCS samples, respectively.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/495/1/10.1093_mnras_staa1062/1/m_staa1062fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611448910&amp;Signature=y~LTR~B8Dl~0nJhe2GE4msK3PSeuEx8DNrSCGhW3ccrXnsIQTzJuLh~Zo8dpbSEFgtMyzgIGjEBHOPBnj02Ml~iibRfCP-AdIjKJxeAX6n05zLpZkrnIEO~BI4NPnn5muIeWh8MknkjyitB5Q0vS2Do5QNi~m8~T5kZQgg2IUgJ7sfLlVKWiQW8fw1qMZMjrIjcOWEe5~Yg2r6CCy8qrxUBkdkQICQFCgfPqnp07MAsyLkxRWm-Vhcb2VnZu-JRFTib54dt0D7tUzHAtljWeHFoJNcl8n4QAsxD51cYbqIWuerWcx~kof3PDcWP-soQ0xq7bLaJI-7D8mnJ4Bjd-3Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Left: Photometric redshift distributions of group-to-cluster-scale lens candidates. The peak of the redshift distributions for both the SuGOHI-c sample (cyan) and the SARCS sample (magenta, More et\u00a0al. 2012) is around z \u223c 0.4. Right: The binned distribution of arc radii for Rarc\u00a0\u2265 2. The peak at around 3\u00a0arcsec attests to the fact that most of the candidates are, indeed, at group scales. As before, cyan and magenta show the SuGOHI-c and the SARCS samples, respectively.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa1062fig5.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/204072643/staa1062fig5.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa1062fig5.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"204072643\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/495/1/10.1093_mnras_staa1062/1/staa1062fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611448910&Signature=O29dAuRLZrg4uK3GizwZECsO~URKb7ed~SuxadPWm6U2784IhnPYJFpQPCnUKNu8Qc62S5EtQUS8vThgOT5lY0m50b7ocs4ADyCjCnt8sXoI20mcnBHRhRl7gS2nNHNHpGm-ExRyAMqvO4GTgqNK-V4b1ryUfeGWV2OXdWNL6dNyk5Jat5Ef9n2-HQkLbnJFT94kGKv7hs~Y~xKVPZsWoWUuIGwVFxZFOxWMv~EHYZ4NGUBPyQJma64K9PQYubdrXW~Z~oxvuAkiPhNefTykjLajWk1D9jTlo-61L5gvB7m1OJ0U~BV89mdp3lf7VDuOvnwAkuOX-RjDdGJ9Hb8dnQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=204072643&ar=5823146&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa1062fig5.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Left:</em> Photometric redshift distributions of group-to-cluster-scale lens candidates. The peak of the redshift distributions for both the SuGOHI-c sample (cyan) and the SARCS sample (magenta, More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) is around <em>z</em> \u223c 0.4. <em>Right:</em> The binned distribution of arc radii for <em>R</em><sub>arc</sub>\u00a0\u2265 2. The peak at around 3\u00a0arcsec attests to the fact that most of the candidates are, indeed, at group scales. As before, cyan and magenta show the SuGOHI-c and the SARCS samples, respectively.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">During our inspection, we also found a number of strong lens systems with red-coloured sources (e.g. HSC J0211\u20130343, HSC J1143+0102). We mark such systems with a \u2020 in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>. Some of them are high redshift galaxies at <em>z</em> \u223c 6 (Oguri et\u00a0al., in preparation, and Ono et\u00a0al., in preparation). We further note that HSC J2211\u20130008 has a spectroscopically confirmed lensed source, which is a Lyman-break galaxy at <em>z</em>\u00a0= 2.26. Details of the follow-up Subaru observations and analysis of this system will be reported in More et\u00a0al. (in preparation).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=204072645 id=\"204072645\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>5 SPECTROSCOPIC FOLLOW-UP</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We carried out spectroscopic observations of 10 candidates from SuGOHI-c sample in order to confirm the lensing nature and obtain spectroscopic redshifts essential for detailed mass modelling of strong lenses (Jaelani et\u00a0al., in preparation). Our sample was part of the larger spectroscopic campaign for SuGOHI lenses (ESO programme 099.A-0220, PI: S. Suyu) with the Very Large Telescope (VLT)\u2019s X-shooter. These candidates were selected from an early sample of grade A-B lenses with <em>z</em><sub>\u2113</sub> &gt; 0.6 from a smaller footprint. X-shooter is an Echelle spectrograph (Vernet et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib92\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib92\" data-open=\"bib92\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>), with an allowed wavelength range of \u03bb\u03bb3000\u201325\u2009000\u00a0\u00c5. The spectra are acquired through three arms, the ultraviolet (UVB, \u03bb\u03bb3000\u20135500\u00a0\u00c5), the visual (VIS, \u03bb\u03bb5000\u201310\u2009500\u00a0\u00c5), and the near-infrared (NIR, \u03bb\u03bb10\u2009000\u201325\u2009000\u00a0\u00c5). The lensed sources were observed using slit widths of 1.0, 0.9, and 0.9 arcsec in the UVB, VIS, and NIR arms, respectively, with a binning of 2\u00a0\u00d7\u00a02 applied to the UVB and VIS data. We set the position angle (PA) of the long slit to be preferentially along the lensed arc (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>). In order to optimize sky background subtraction, we dithered the observations in the standard ABBA nodding pattern.</p>                        <a id=\"204072647\" scrollto-destination=\"204072647\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/495/1/10.1093_mnras_staa1062/1/m_staa1062fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611448910&amp;Signature=oh051O8auJNLR9gNSQtZbh13RSHpX3jZKna5dKeECFcNekurtp6bm-mY4ptOxjPf9F8h58BO8ltfuG2NyiR9met5ZNVvZ2rrz6E90XOQ~ZJgqbE4oA84QOYgW1DojcmyWXnNhjWkY2~WlMJiMKwSavT-WcWIc~tv0tXTBzqjm94DzwPUSTpkA-1O953wEyExRKpst-7gUtQMT0Aq9RSl6g2enKmrdJfuEEoNnCBTDa0qxl2Tc8bRYF2FgYC0zbNY1f5ywcLjB4BgZiA7Ys6x9csYR-DOTrZgDNhuajyGQPBY0jUN6WKs25CEgv9MQQDXDjeA4zvbCCOs3BcGws5c-g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Spectroscopic results from the X-shooter observations. Each row is for one candidate lens. One candidate (HSC J2213+0048) with no detection is shown in image only here. On the left, we show the alignment of the slit on the putative lensed source that was observed. The brightest lens galaxies are denoted by 'G'. On the right, the upper panel (for each row) shows regions from the 2D spectrum where interesting features are expected. The red (and blue) dashed lines show the exact region used for extracting the 1D spectrum of one of the lensed images (and its counterpart). The bottom panel shows the corresponding stacked 1D spectra (red) where the vertical lines highlight the location of expected emission lines. The labels for those emission lines are shown at the top of the figure. The error on the spectrum is shown by a shaded region (grey) and Gaussian fits to the emission lines are in black. The semi-transparent panels show the locations of some of the common emission lines, which are not detected, for the given source redshift.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa1062fig6.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/204072647/staa1062fig6.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa1062fig6.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"204072647\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/495/1/10.1093_mnras_staa1062/1/staa1062fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611448910&Signature=Cae745drTrp4L1yp8Kmfege0FBe-C3QQ2MNwOXAjDhbNSK9oYqRL9oNHN3CD6Qvtks3AfOT6PAtOjCQE2icI6sVTyewts4LwXhWbPG203Ve04R4nAqhTaFw7DAEB5YmymaT7ihxkoW6YjKHRDDWteI07WT44Ddw~PPujV9yYbp7NS0PiUilGoc-Eypfh4lILjvMMCZCjUMKEELDAQ0edyaO8sdQhxQbx3AY~nyn7YvoanDr~jNE3G1qaQv4MfC7gBgmENah8cbmnSDhgsTlj8MHiwmXlJfISizLFN-fd1Tj4ByAedM8FNw9fhW-dG5LX21VdeoPw36dzass6IV7jwA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=204072647&ar=5823146&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa1062fig6.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Spectroscopic results from the X-shooter observations. Each row is for one candidate lens. One candidate (HSC J2213+0048) with no detection is shown in image only here. On the left, we show the alignment of the slit on the putative lensed source that was observed. The brightest lens galaxies are denoted by 'G'. On the right, the upper panel (for each row) shows regions from the 2D spectrum where interesting features are expected. The red (and blue) dashed lines show the exact region used for extracting the 1D spectrum of one of the lensed images (and its counterpart). The bottom panel shows the corresponding stacked 1D spectra (red) where the vertical lines highlight the location of expected emission lines. The labels for those emission lines are shown at the top of the figure. The error on the spectrum is shown by a shaded region (grey) and Gaussian fits to the emission lines are in black. The semi-transparent panels show the locations of some of the common emission lines, which are not detected, for the given source redshift.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/495/1/10.1093_mnras_staa1062/1/m_staa1062fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611448910&amp;Signature=oh051O8auJNLR9gNSQtZbh13RSHpX3jZKna5dKeECFcNekurtp6bm-mY4ptOxjPf9F8h58BO8ltfuG2NyiR9met5ZNVvZ2rrz6E90XOQ~ZJgqbE4oA84QOYgW1DojcmyWXnNhjWkY2~WlMJiMKwSavT-WcWIc~tv0tXTBzqjm94DzwPUSTpkA-1O953wEyExRKpst-7gUtQMT0Aq9RSl6g2enKmrdJfuEEoNnCBTDa0qxl2Tc8bRYF2FgYC0zbNY1f5ywcLjB4BgZiA7Ys6x9csYR-DOTrZgDNhuajyGQPBY0jUN6WKs25CEgv9MQQDXDjeA4zvbCCOs3BcGws5c-g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Spectroscopic results from the X-shooter observations. Each row is for one candidate lens. One candidate (HSC J2213+0048) with no detection is shown in image only here. On the left, we show the alignment of the slit on the putative lensed source that was observed. The brightest lens galaxies are denoted by 'G'. On the right, the upper panel (for each row) shows regions from the 2D spectrum where interesting features are expected. The red (and blue) dashed lines show the exact region used for extracting the 1D spectrum of one of the lensed images (and its counterpart). The bottom panel shows the corresponding stacked 1D spectra (red) where the vertical lines highlight the location of expected emission lines. The labels for those emission lines are shown at the top of the figure. The error on the spectrum is shown by a shaded region (grey) and Gaussian fits to the emission lines are in black. The semi-transparent panels show the locations of some of the common emission lines, which are not detected, for the given source redshift.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa1062fig6.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/204072647/staa1062fig6.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa1062fig6.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"204072647\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/495/1/10.1093_mnras_staa1062/1/staa1062fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611448910&Signature=Cae745drTrp4L1yp8Kmfege0FBe-C3QQ2MNwOXAjDhbNSK9oYqRL9oNHN3CD6Qvtks3AfOT6PAtOjCQE2icI6sVTyewts4LwXhWbPG203Ve04R4nAqhTaFw7DAEB5YmymaT7ihxkoW6YjKHRDDWteI07WT44Ddw~PPujV9yYbp7NS0PiUilGoc-Eypfh4lILjvMMCZCjUMKEELDAQ0edyaO8sdQhxQbx3AY~nyn7YvoanDr~jNE3G1qaQv4MfC7gBgmENah8cbmnSDhgsTlj8MHiwmXlJfISizLFN-fd1Tj4ByAedM8FNw9fhW-dG5LX21VdeoPw36dzass6IV7jwA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=204072647&ar=5823146&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa1062fig6.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Spectroscopic results from the X-shooter observations. Each row is for one candidate lens. One candidate (HSC J2213+0048) with no detection is shown in image only here. On the left, we show the alignment of the slit on the putative lensed source that was observed. The brightest lens galaxies are denoted by 'G'. On the right, the upper panel (for each row) shows regions from the 2D spectrum where interesting features are expected. The red (and blue) dashed lines show the exact region used for extracting the 1D spectrum of one of the lensed images (and its counterpart). The bottom panel shows the corresponding stacked 1D spectra (red) where the vertical lines highlight the location of expected emission lines. The labels for those emission lines are shown at the top of the figure. The error on the spectrum is shown by a shaded region (grey) and Gaussian fits to the emission lines are in black. The semi-transparent panels show the locations of some of the common emission lines, which are not detected, for the given source redshift.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Each system was observed in slit mode during either one (e.g. HSC J0224\u20130336) or two (e.g. HSC J1202+0039) observation blocks (OBs) to reach the optimal signal-to-noise ratio. Each OB corresponds to roughly 1 h of telescope time and consists of 10\u00a0\u00d7\u00a0285\u2009s exposures obtained in an ABBA nodding pattern to optimize background subtraction in the NIR arm. Exposure times in the UVB and VIS arms are slightly shorter due to the longer readout time. Observations were executed with seeing full width at half-maximum &lt;0.9\u00a0arcsec on target position. Initially, we reduce the spectroscopic data using the ESO <span class=\"small-caps\">reflex</span> software (version 2.9.0) combined with X-shooter pipeline recipes (v3.1.0) (Modigliani et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib59\" data-open=\"bib59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Freudling et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). The pipeline recipes perform standard bias subtraction and flat-fielding of the raw spectra. Cosmic rays are removed using <span class=\"small-caps\">lacosmic</span> (van Dokkum <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib88\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib88\" data-open=\"bib88\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>). For each arm, we extract the orders and rectify them in wavelength space using a wavelength solution previously obtained from the calibration frames. The resulting rectified orders are then shifted, co-added, and flux calibrated to obtain the final two-dimensional (2D) spectrum. For further data processing and analysis, we use standard <span class=\"small-caps\">iraf</span> tools. We produce one-dimensional (1D) spectra using an extraction aperture in all three arms and for all three images of the source (apertures are shown by red and blue dashed line on Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=204072649 id=\"204072649\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1>5.1 Redshift measurement</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We visually inspected all of the three arms of the X-shooter (2D and 1D) spectra in order to identify any emission and/or absorption lines arising from the lensed galaxies. We identified a set of emission lines that could be attributed to a common redshift. We fitted Gaussian profiles to each of those lines in order to determine their central wavelength and, thereby, determined a mean redshift for each lensed galaxy. Most of the lensed arcs showed [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] doublet \u03bb3726.03, 3728.81\u00a0\u00c5, H\u2009\u03b4 \u03bb4101.73\u00a0\u00c5, H\u2009\u03b3 \u03bb4340.46\u00a0\u00c5, H\u2009\u03b2 \u03bb4861.32\u00a0\u00c5, [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] \u03bb4958.91, 5006.84\u00a0\u00c5, H\u2009\u03b1 \u03bb6562.79\u00a0\u00c5, [N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] \u03bb6583.45\u00a0\u00c5, [S\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] \u03bb6716.43, and \u03bb6730.81\u00a0\u00c5, which are expected to be found in blue star-forming galaxies. Our lensed galaxies span a redshift range from <em>z</em> \u223c 0.9 to 2.2 (summarized in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>). We give a short description of the confirmed lenses below.</p>                        <a id=\"204072651\" scrollto-destination=\"204072651\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl4\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl4\" data-id=\"tbl4\"><span class=\"label\">Table 4.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of X-shooter spectroscopic observations. Position angles (PA) are measured east of north.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Name<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Obs. Date<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>PA<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>z</em><sub>s</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(UT)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(deg)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>HSC J0224\u20130336\u00a0</td><td>13-07-2017\u00a0</td><td>25\u00a0</td><td>1.514\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HSC J0904+0125\u00a0</td><td>09-04-2017\u00a0</td><td>5\u00a0</td><td>2.176\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HSC J0907+0057\u00a0</td><td>29-01-2018\u00a0</td><td>25\u00a0</td><td>1.916\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HSC J1147\u20130013\u00a0</td><td>28-02-2018\u00a0</td><td>102\u00a0</td><td>2.093\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HSC J1156\u20130037\u00a0</td><td>07-04-2017\u00a0</td><td>22\u00a0</td><td>1.907\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HSC J1201+0126\u00a0</td><td>07-04-2017\u00a0</td><td>7\u00a0</td><td>1.653\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HSC J1202+0039\u00a0</td><td>06-04-2017\u00a0</td><td>\u221255\u00a0</td><td>1.885\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>01-03-2018\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HSC J2213+0048\u00a0</td><td>10-06-2017\u00a0</td><td>\u221218\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>15-08-2017\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HSC J2226+0041\u00a0</td><td>29-09-2017\u00a0</td><td>\u221250\u00a0</td><td>1.897\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HSC J2233\u20130104\u00a0</td><td>07-08-2017\u00a0</td><td>90\u00a0</td><td>0.902\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Name<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Obs. Date<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>PA<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>z</em><sub>s</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(UT)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(deg)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>HSC J0224\u20130336\u00a0</td><td>13-07-2017\u00a0</td><td>25\u00a0</td><td>1.514\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HSC J0904+0125\u00a0</td><td>09-04-2017\u00a0</td><td>5\u00a0</td><td>2.176\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HSC J0907+0057\u00a0</td><td>29-01-2018\u00a0</td><td>25\u00a0</td><td>1.916\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HSC J1147\u20130013\u00a0</td><td>28-02-2018\u00a0</td><td>102\u00a0</td><td>2.093\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HSC J1156\u20130037\u00a0</td><td>07-04-2017\u00a0</td><td>22\u00a0</td><td>1.907\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HSC J1201+0126\u00a0</td><td>07-04-2017\u00a0</td><td>7\u00a0</td><td>1.653\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HSC J1202+0039\u00a0</td><td>06-04-2017\u00a0</td><td>\u221255\u00a0</td><td>1.885\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>01-03-2018\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HSC J2213+0048\u00a0</td><td>10-06-2017\u00a0</td><td>\u221218\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>15-08-2017\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HSC J2226+0041\u00a0</td><td>29-09-2017\u00a0</td><td>\u221250\u00a0</td><td>1.897\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HSC J2233\u20130104\u00a0</td><td>07-08-2017\u00a0</td><td>90\u00a0</td><td>0.902\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA; J0904+0125\u00a0</td><td>09-04-2017\u00a0</td><td>5\u00a0</td><td>2.176\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HSC J0907+0057\u00a0</td><td>29-01-2018\u00a0</td><td>25\u00a0</td><td>1.916\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HSC J1156\u20130037\u00a0</td><td>07-04-2017\u00a0</td><td>22\u00a0</td><td>1.907\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HSC J1201+0126\u00a0</td><td>07-04-2017\u00a0</td><td>7\u00a0</td><td>1.653\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HSC J2213+0048\u00a0</td><td>10-06-2017\u00a0</td><td>\u221218\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>15-08-2017\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HSC J2226+0041\u00a0</td><td>29-09-2017\u00a0</td><td>\u221250\u00a0</td><td>1.897\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HSC J2233\u20130104\u00a0</td><td>07-08-2017\u00a0</td><td>90\u00a0</td><td>0.902\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Name<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Obs. Date<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>PA<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>z</em><sub>s</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(UT)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(deg)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>HSC J0224\u20130336\u00a0</td><td>13-07-2017\u00a0</td><td>25\u00a0</td><td>1.514\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HSC J0904+0125\u00a0</td><td>09-04-2017\u00a0</td><td>5\u00a0</td><td>2.176\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HSC J0907+0057\u00a0</td><td>29-01-2018\u00a0</td><td>25\u00a0</td><td>1.916\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HSC J1147\u20130013\u00a0</td><td>28-02-2018\u00a0</td><td>102\u00a0</td><td>2.093\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HSC J1156\u20130037\u00a0</td><td>07-04-2017\u00a0</td><td>22\u00a0</td><td>1.907\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HSC J1201+0126\u00a0</td><td>07-04-2017\u00a0</td><td>7\u00a0</td><td>1.653\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HSC J1202+0039\u00a0</td><td>06-04-2017\u00a0</td><td>\u221255\u00a0</td><td>1.885\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>01-03-2018\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HSC J2213+0048\u00a0</td><td>10-06-2017\u00a0</td><td>\u221218\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>15-08-2017\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HSC J2226+0041\u00a0</td><td>29-09-2017\u00a0</td><td>\u221250\u00a0</td><td>1.897\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HSC J2233\u20130104\u00a0</td><td>07-08-2017\u00a0</td><td>90\u00a0</td><td>0.902\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/204072651\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=204072652 id=\"204072652\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-2>5.2 Spectroscopically confirmed group-scale lenses</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>HSC J0224\u20130336</em> at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z_{\\ell ,\\rm spec}=0.613$|\u2060</span>: This system has been reported in More et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) and has four bright early-type galaxies at the centre, surrounded by a blue arc (almost complete ring). We set the slit along the arc to the north-west of the lens (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>) that has a peak flux in <em>g</em>band. Most of the emission lines in this system are detected in the NIR arm of X-shooter, H\u2009\u03b2, [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>], H\u2009\u03b1, [N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>], and [S\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]. We also detected the [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] doublet in the VIS arm. These emission lines correspond to a mean redshift of <em>z</em>\u00a0= 1.514. The lens galaxy, 'G' of HSC J0224\u20130336 shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>, is identified as the centre of the cluster by Wen et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib93\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib93\" data-open=\"bib93\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), which has a richness of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$N_{\\rm ric,{W{\\small EN}}}= 21.62$|</span> with 14 member galaxies and corresponds to <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{200}\\approx 1.18\\times 10^{14} {\\, \\mathrm{M}_{\\odot }}$|\u2060</span>. However, the same galaxy is identified as a member galaxy of a cluster, in <span class=\"small-caps\">camira</span>, with a richness of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$N_{\\rm ric,{\\small CAMIRA}}= 19.62$|\u2060</span>, 63 member galaxies, and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{200}\\approx 6.36\\times 10^{13} {\\, \\mathrm{M}_{\\odot }}$|\u2060</span>. The stellar velocity dispersion of the lens galaxy is 448\u00a0\u00b1\u00a0101 <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\, \\rm km\\, s^{-1}$|</span> from the SDSS data.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>HSCJ0904+0125</em> at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z_{\\ell ,\\rm phot}=0.914$|\u2060</span>: For this system, we set the slit along a nearly north\u2013south blue arc. We detected emission lines such as the [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] doublet, H\u2009\u03b2, [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>], and H\u2009\u03b1 in NIR arm corresponding to a mean redshift of <em>z</em>\u00a0= 2.176. The lens galaxy of the system, 'G' in HSCJ0904+0125 panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>, is identified as the galaxy member in <span class=\"small-caps\">camira</span>. The cluster has a richness <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$N_{\\rm ric,{\\small CAMIRA}}= 18.37$|</span> with 56 member galaxies and corresponds to <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{200}\\approx 5.83\\times 10^{13} {\\, \\mathrm{M}_{\\odot }}$|\u2060</span>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>HSC J0907+0057</em> at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z_{\\ell ,\\rm phot}=0.723$|\u2060</span>: This system is composed of a number of blue arcs around a bright early-type galaxy at a separation \u2243 5\u00a0arcsec. We set a slit along the east-most arc-like component whose light is not contaminated by any red blobs (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>). We detect weak emission lines such as the [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] doublet and [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>]\u2009\u03bb5008.24\u00a0\u00c5 line, yielding a lensed galaxy redshift of <em>z</em>\u00a0= 1.916. The lens galaxy, 'G' of HSC J0907+0057 shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>, is at the centre of the cluster in <span class=\"small-caps\">camira</span>, which has a richness of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$N_{\\rm ric,{\\small CAMIRA}}= 35.49$|</span> and 75 member galaxies corresponding to <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{200}\\approx 1.38\\times 10^{14} {\\, \\mathrm{M}_{\\odot }}$|\u2060</span>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>HSC J1147\u20130013</em> at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z_{\\ell ,\\rm phot}=0.805$|\u2060</span>: We detect many strong emission lines such as [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] doublet, H\u2009\u03b3, H\u2009\u03b2, [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>], and H\u2009\u03b1 in the NIR arm from the nearly straight blue arcs. This system has similar features to HSC J0904+0125, which has a small peak near main peak. We find that the emission lines correspond to a mean redshift of <em>z</em>\u00a0= 2.093. This group-scale system is found serendipitously during the inspection owing to the very bright arc next to another cluster. The cluster catalogues may have missed this due to lack of sufficiently bright galaxies.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>HSC J1156\u20130037</em> at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z_{\\ell ,\\rm phot}=0.918$|\u2060</span>: We find that the blue arc has a mean redshift of <em>z</em>\u00a0= 1.907 from the emission lines [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] doublet, H\u2009\u03b3, H\u2009\u03b2, [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>], and H\u2009\u03b1 in the NIR arm. The lens galaxy, 'G' of HSC J1156\u20130037 shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>, is found to be a galaxy member of the large cluster in <span class=\"small-caps\">camira</span>, which has a high richness of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$N_{\\rm ric,{\\small CAMIRA}}= 64.05$|</span> corresponding to <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{200}\\approx 3.00\\times 10^{14} {\\, \\mathrm{M}_{\\odot }}$|\u2060</span>. This cluster has 126 member galaxies.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>HSC J1201+0126</em> at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z_{\\ell ,\\rm phot}=0.618$|\u2060</span>: This system has been reported in Petrillo et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). We set the slit along the blue arc, which has a small early-type galaxy included (which produces the continuum in the 2D spectra). We detect weak continuum from early-type galaxy and strong emission lines, H\u2009\u03b2, [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] and H\u2009\u03b1 in NIR arm and [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] doublet in VIS arm, yielding a lensed galaxy redshift of <em>z</em>\u00a0= 1.653. The lens galaxy, 'G' of HSC J1201+0126 shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>, is at the centre of the cluster as per <span class=\"small-caps\">camira</span>, which has a richness of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$N_{\\rm ric,{\\small CAMIRA}}= 36.23$|</span> with 67 member galaxies and corresponds to <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{200}\\approx 1.42\\times 10^{14} {\\, \\mathrm{M}_{\\odot }}$|\u2060</span>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>HSC J1202+0039</em> at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z_{\\ell ,\\rm spec}=0.689$|\u2060</span>: As seen in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>, the slit targeting this system covers the source in two locations, the East and North of the lens. We detect strong emission lines [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>]\u2009\u03bb4960.30\u00a0\u00c5 and [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>]\u2009\u03bb5008.24\u00a0\u00c5 in each source location. We find that the emission lines have a mean redshift of <em>z</em>\u00a0= 1.885. The lens galaxy, 'G' of HSC J1202+0039 shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>, is identified as the BCG as per <span class=\"small-caps\">camira</span>, which has a richness of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$N_{\\rm ric,{\\small CAMIRA}}= 36.298$|</span> with 75 member galaxies and corresponding to <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{200}\\approx 1.42\\times 10^{14} {\\, \\mathrm{M}_{\\odot }}$|\u2060</span>. The stellar velocity dispersion of the BCG is 238\u00a0\u00b1\u00a037 <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\, \\rm km\\, s^{-1}$|</span> from the SDSS data.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>HSC J2213+0048</em> at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z_{\\ell ,\\rm phot}=0.945$|\u2060</span>: We do not detect continuum or any features from emission or absorption in the spectrum of this system. The lens galaxy, 'G' of HSC J2213+0048 shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>, is identified as a member of a group in Ford et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), which has a richness of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$N_{\\rm ric,{F{\\small ORD}}}= 8.80$|</span> with 68 member galaxies, corresponding to <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{200}\\approx 7.29\\times 10^{12} {\\, \\mathrm{M}_{\\odot }}$|\u2060</span>. This system also has been reported in More et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). <em>HSC J2226+0041</em> at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z_{\\ell ,\\rm spec}=0.647$|\u2060</span>: This is a known lens system (Diehl et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Sonnenfeld et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib79\" data-open=\"bib79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Jacobs et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). We measure a mean redshift of <em>z</em>\u00a0= 1.897 from emission lines such as [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] (assuming the rest-frame centroid of the unresolved [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] doublet \u2009\u03bb3728.3\u00a0\u00c5), H\u2009\u03b3, H\u2009\u03b2, [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>]\u2009\u03bb4960.30\u00a0\u00c5, [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>]\u2009\u03bb5008.24\u00a0\u00c5, and H\u2009\u03b1. The stellar velocity dispersion of the lens galaxy, 'G' of HSC J2226+0041 shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>, is 318\u00a0\u00b1\u00a047 <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\, \\rm km\\, s^{-1}$|</span> from the SDSS data.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>HSC J2233\u20130104</em> at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z_{\\ell ,\\rm phot}=0.953$|\u2060</span>: We detect three probable blue arcs: a long-thin arc and a short arc to the north-east of the lens, and a third short arc to the north of the lens (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>). We set the slit along the northern arc and detect some emission lines: an unresolved [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] doublet \u03bb3728.30, [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>]\u2009\u03bb4960.30\u00a0\u00c5, [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>]\u2009\u03bb5008.24\u00a0\u00c5, H\u2009\u03b1, [N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>], and also weak emission of H\u2009\u03b2. The emission lines suggest a mean redshift of <em>z</em>\u00a0= 0.902, indicating that the arc is probably not a lensed galaxy since the redshift of this arc is close to the photometric redshift of the lens galaxy, 'G' of HSC J2233\u20130104 shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"204072662\" scrollto-destination=\"204072662\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/495/1/10.1093_mnras_staa1062/1/m_staa1062fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611448910&amp;Signature=kxb~jrPctLSx1OIxsZVsyPqgQZwos1madZBpIN5pfKTmkICZ3IRdOAgYfUJLc9ScAwT1~5x2jG3-z2kR3mU5xstXPd842DFnwuBH5HJpaoGKx1AaHgOH8JLU9DLjIVf9b1q3gxEanGX8iRsV-4aW09tDlR6YXpAGUm9b6cNHHMzrjjHn7ch0kRm8bshTJgfr2uuooURHU4uAeiTwF~ZJNPepJPF10h4rLT3qxT9zKquFgFfaYQYHGJn-8kvS7Maied1OyseoNi3Ef3zhoQnJucQRdAral65pRgJL5JlOH~D-zhVz9xvdE5bwh1MYhXBsL1OfIntXWKoBxiHVAmYoQg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"HSC J2233\u20130104 lens candidate. Image is \u223c43\u00a0arcsec on the side. The bar shows a scale of 10\u00a0arcsec.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/495/1/10.1093_mnras_staa1062/1/m_staa1062fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611448910&amp;Signature=kxb~jrPctLSx1OIxsZVsyPqgQZwos1madZBpIN5pfKTmkICZ3IRdOAgYfUJLc9ScAwT1~5x2jG3-z2kR3mU5xstXPd842DFnwuBH5HJpaoGKx1AaHgOH8JLU9DLjIVf9b1q3gxEanGX8iRsV-4aW09tDlR6YXpAGUm9b6cNHHMzrjjHn7ch0kRm8bshTJgfr2uuooURHU4uAeiTwF~ZJNPepJPF10h4rLT3qxT9zKquFgFfaYQYHGJn-8kvS7Maied1OyseoNi3Ef3zhoQnJucQRdAral65pRgJL5JlOH~D-zhVz9xvdE5bwh1MYhXBsL1OfIntXWKoBxiHVAmYoQg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"HSC J2233\u20130104 lens candidate. Image is \u223c43\u00a0arcsec on the side. The bar shows a scale of 10\u00a0arcsec.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa1062fig7.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/204072662/staa1062fig7.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa1062fig7.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"204072662\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/495/1/10.1093_mnras_staa1062/1/staa1062fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611448910&Signature=jgZnNVyyk7MiTOXrnKaErNlhmXtq0j7opX-~t2zWiJ6lpsFVdAeChMGMdPtbCDBgqrrPpzXjpyA40hlMd-dcyKwXoE6dWG8DrspdDFmTqBIbsCp2YsslYh9kQn81xoPn8L-~Av1vIsM2vZ4GpPnydkjP9a07tDeK9QtPjJG0MD9E4d13Wu9ZEAHPfF9IF1wEQc1mWWt11JbvTQjnYucukSstycEnY7PtMbfp6tk9wLSURNhLkjAWCc716UUonH3xZegnDqhx5PgcNb5WfIIChLx8R5K4yd3cOTA~aCiWEiwLKNleUykQz7s0Ue7etkfbnOHKwI~waAE3X5Ygk0HR7Q__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=204072662&ar=5823146&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa1062fig7.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">HSC J2233\u20130104 lens candidate. Image is \u223c43\u00a0arcsec on the side. The bar shows a scale of 10\u00a0arcsec.</p></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=204072663 id=\"204072663\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6>6 SUMMARY AND CONCLUSION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We have carried out the largest ever systematic search for strong gravitational lens systems at group-to-cluster-scales. Since the S18A release of the HSC\u2013SSP Survey, covering nearly 1114\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup>, we have visually inspected 39\u2009435 groups and clusters selected from four parent cluster catalogues. While <span class=\"small-caps\">camira</span> catalogue was obtained from HSC imaging, other catalogues (Wen et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib93\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib93\" data-open=\"bib93\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Ford et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Rykoff et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib77\" data-open=\"bib77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) came from previous surveys with overlapping footprints.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our search resulted in a total of 641 lens candidates with 228 highly promising (grade A-B) candidates and 413 plausible (grade C) candidates. Additionally, we report 131 galaxy-scale lens candidates found serendipitously during our search. Most of these are new and are missed from the previously reported SuGOHI-g samples (see Appendix\u00a0\u00a0<a class=\"js-jumplink\" href=\"#sec7\">A</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The SuGOHI-c will enable detailed studies of mass distributions in individual systems for even low-mass galaxy groups at low-to-intermediate redshifts and clusters at very high redshifts. Furthermore, the large sample size will surpass any of the previous statistical studies of group-scale lenses. Finally, we have nearly six times more lenses at high redshifts (<em>z</em><sub>\u2113</sub> &gt; 0.8) compared to the previous high-redshift SARCS sample. Thus, we will be able to study evolution in the mass distributions at these mass scales for the first time.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The SuGOHI-c sample has many striking systems with blue giant arcs, red-lensed galaxies, and in some cases, multiple-lensed galaxies from distinct redshifts lensed by the same galaxy groups. We also present the results of our spectroscopic follow-up with X-shooter where, for nine out of the 10 candidates, we could detect emission lines and successfully measure the redshifts of the lensed galaxies. A detailed mass modelling analysis using spectroscopic results will be presented in the near future.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=204072668 id=\"204072668\" class=\"backacknowledgements-title\" data-legacy-id=ack1>ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The authors would like to thank the referee for improving the presentation of the paper. ATJ and KTI are supported by JSPS KAKENHI Grant Number JP17H02868. MO is supported by JSPS KAKENHI Grant Number JP15H05892 and JP18K03693. IK is supported by JSPS KAKENHI Grant Number JP15H05896. SHS thanks the Max Planck Society for support through the Max Planck Research Group. JHHC acknowledges support from the Swiss National Science Foundation (SNSF). This work was supported in part by World Premier International Research centre Initiative (WPI Initiative), MEXT, Japan.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The Hyper Suprime-Cam (HSC) collaboration includes the astronomical communities of Japan and Taiwan, and Princeton University. The HSC instrumentation and software were developed by the National Astronomical Observatory of Japan (NAOJ), the Kavli Institute for the Physics and Mathematics of the Universe (Kavli IPMU), the University of Tokyo, the High Energy Accelerator Research Organization (KEK), the Academia Sinica Institute for Astronomy and Astrophysics in Taiwan (ASIAA), and Princeton University. Funding was contributed by the FIRST program from the Japanese Cabinet Office, the Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology (MEXT), the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science (JSPS), Japan Science and Technology Agency (JST), the Toray Science Foundation, NAOJ, Kavli IPMU, KEK, ASIAA, and Princeton University.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This paper makes use of software developed for the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope. We thank the LSST Project for making their code available as free software at <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://dm.lsst.org\" target=\"_blank\">http://dm.lsst.org</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This paper is based [in part] on data collected at the Subaru Telescope and retrieved from the HSC data archive system, which is operated by Subaru Telescope and Astronomy Data Center (ADC) at NAOJ. Data analysis was in part carried out with the cooperation of Center for Computational Astrophysics (CfCA), NAOJ.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The Pan-STARRS1 Surveys (PS1) and the PS1 public science archive have been made possible through contributions by the Institute for Astronomy, the University of Hawaii, the Pan-STARRS Project Office, the Max-Planck Society and its participating institutes, the Max Planck Institute for Astronomy, Heidelberg, and the Max Planck Institute for Extraterrestrial Physics, Garching, The Johns Hopkins University, Durham University, the University of Edinburgh, Queen\u2019s University Belfast, the Harvard-Smithsonian centre for Astrophysics, the Las Cumbres Observatory Global Telescope Network Incorporated, the National Central University of Taiwan, the Space Telescope Science Institute, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration under Grant No. NNX08AR22G issued through the Planetary Science Division of the NASA Science Mission Directorate, the National Science Foundation under Grant No. AST-1238877, the University of Maryland, Eotvos Lorand University (ELTE), the Los Alamos National Laboratory, and the Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Based (in part) on data collected at the Subaru Telescope and retrieved from the HSC data archive system, which is operated by Subaru Telescope and Astronomy Data centre at National Astronomical Observatory of Japan.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Funding for the SDSS IV has been provided by the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation, the U.S. Department of Energy Office of Science, and the Participating Institutions. SDSS acknowledges support and resources from the centre for High-Performance Computing at the University of Utah. The SDSS website is <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://www.sdss.org\" target=\"_blank\">www.sdss.org</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">SDSS is managed by the Astrophysical Research Consortium for the Participating Institutions of the SDSS Collaboration including the Brazilian Participation Group, the Carnegie Institution for Science, Carnegie Mellon University, the Chilean Participation Group, the French Participation Group, Harvard-Smithsonian centre for Astrophysics, Instituto de Astrof\u00edsica de Canarias, the Johns Hopkins University, Kavli Institute for Observatories of China, New Mexico State University, New York University, University of Notre Dame, Observat\u00f3rio Nacional/MCTI, The Ohio State University, Pennsylvania State University, Shanghai case 1--><div class=\"citation-links\"></div><div class=\"citation-links\"><div class=\"crossref-doi js-ref-link\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" class=\"inst-open-url-holders\" data-targetId=\"10.1088%2F0004-637X%2F703%2F2%2FL132\"> </span></div>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=204072684 id=\"204072684\" class=\"appendix-title\" data-legacy-id=sec7>APPENDIX A: ADDITIONAL SERENDIPITOUS LENS CANDIDATES FROM THE HSC\u2013SSP S18A</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">During our visual inspection of galaxy groups and clusters, some galaxy-scale lenses were discovered serendipitously, which happen to be either member galaxies of the group or field galaxies in the vicinity. Since the lensing is due to an individual galaxy rather than a group/cluster (e.g. see the right most panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>), these systems are excluded from our formal SuGOHI-c sample and are reported here instead.</p>                        <a id=\"204072686\" scrollto-destination=\"204072686\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"figa1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure A1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/495/1/10.1093_mnras_staa1062/1/m_staa1062figa1.jpeg?Expires=1611448910&amp;Signature=3MQp3oJagc7r3vgizTAMoZulhTKx7Sc~as2PpmtzDAUXzlFrAuPtE0~QB8wI4BAcg5xTwS~q~DsCrVQBZXEe1DXxktymWyWzy1deJSFHxyF1u7Sz~Q7PwMSGiMJFLsc-BoChJ6XNFQrEYDd58cnwznaaZS2IGdklb~f1H3OsGcgR26l6eRn2BGLiQ4oHhyGlyecIyb5cAQ8K2ebBqH4WpXrCZgPonrJAEW1~MByUGcJTwozsjdtDCKOERkQhqZbkC0fMHRlJ221KYveBlfMiz85o5lzKITWi0ARQlCwTCMPLw~s-0fambCA7KTPLe88K4H-sfZhJUEHuT4MYIYiNsQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Similar to Fig.\u00a03, the distribution of lens candidates at galaxy scales according to the parent cluster catalogues with Rarc\u00a0&lt; 2\u00a0arcsec. The Venn diagram is divided into two panels: 69 lens systems of SuGOHI-g correspond to the parent cluster (upper) and 62 lens systems, which are serendipitously (bottom) discovered during the inspection.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"figa1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure A1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/495/1/10.1093_mnras_staa1062/1/m_staa1062figa1.jpeg?Expires=1611448910&amp;Signature=3MQp3oJagc7r3vgizTAMoZulhTKx7Sc~as2PpmtzDAUXzlFrAuPtE0~QB8wI4BAcg5xTwS~q~DsCrVQBZXEe1DXxktymWyWzy1deJSFHxyF1u7Sz~Q7PwMSGiMJFLsc-BoChJ6XNFQrEYDd58cnwznaaZS2IGdklb~f1H3OsGcgR26l6eRn2BGLiQ4oHhyGlyecIyb5cAQ8K2ebBqH4WpXrCZgPonrJAEW1~MByUGcJTwozsjdtDCKOERkQhqZbkC0fMHRlJ221KYveBlfMiz85o5lzKITWi0ARQlCwTCMPLw~s-0fambCA7KTPLe88K4H-sfZhJUEHuT4MYIYiNsQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Similar to Fig.\u00a03, the distribution of lens candidates at galaxy scales according to the parent cluster catalogues with Rarc\u00a0&lt; 2\u00a0arcsec. Redshifts are <span class=\"monospace\">DEmP</span> photometric and SDSS DR15 spectroscopic redshifts. PC indicates the parent cluster catalogue through which a candidate was selected as in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span>1. Systems with \u2020, <sup>X</sup>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$^{\\mathbb {C}}$|\u2060</span>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$^{\\mathbb {D}}$|\u2060</span>, and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$^{\\mathbb {K}}$|</span> are the lens candidates that have red-coloured sources, X-shooter follow-up, spectroscopically confirmed, previously discovered, and known, respectively.           </div>\r\n\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\">\r\n                <h1 class=\"wi-article-title article-title-main\">\r\n                    Survey of Gravitationally lensed Objects in HSC Imaging (SuGOHI) \u2013 V. $(this).siblings('.ati-toggle-content').toggleClass('hide');\r\n        });\r\n\r\n        // In Chrome, an anchor tag with target=\"_blank\" and a \"mailto:\" href opens a new tab/window as well as the email client\r\n        // I suspect this behavior will be corrected in the future\r\n        // Remove the target=\"_blank\"\r\n        $('ul.wi-affiliationList').find('a[href^=\"mailto:\"]').each(function () {\r\n            $(this).removeAttr('target');\r\n        });\r\n    });\r\n</script>\r\n\r\n \n    </div>\n    <div
